unnormalised: Okay, so you're looking to rent a place, eh? Or maybe you're a landlord in Mumbai, ready to welcome a new tenant? Either way, let's talk rental agreements – that all-important piece of paper (or nowadays, a PDF) that keeps everyone happy (or at least, legally covered).
normalised: Okay, so you're looking to rent a place, eh? Or maybe you're a landlord in Mumbai, ready to welcome a new tenant? Either way, let's talk rental agreements – that all-important piece of paper (or nowadays, a P D F) that keeps everyone happy (or at least, legally covered).

unnormalised: Think of a rental agreement like the secret ingredient in your mom's biryani recipe. You can *try* to wing it, but it's gonna be a lot better – and less likely to end in disaster – if you follow a proper recipe. This agreement is your recipe for a smooth landlord-tenant relationship.
normalised: Think of a rental agreement like the secret ingredient in your mom's biryani recipe. You can *try* to wing it, but it's gonna be a lot better – and less likely to end in disaster – if you follow a proper recipe. This agreement is your recipe for a smooth landlord-tenant relationship.

unnormalised: What should you look for in this "recipe"? Well, first off, the basics: names of the parties (Landlord: Mr. Sharma, Tenant: Priya Verma, maybe?), the address of the property (Flat No. 302, Sai Apartments, Bandra), and the monthly rent (Rs. 25,000, negotiable, maybe!).
normalised: What should you look for in this "recipe"? Well, first off, the basics: names of the parties (Landlord: Mister Sharma, Tenant: Priya Verma, maybe?), the address of the property (Flat Number three hundred and two, Sai Apartments, Bandra), and the monthly rent (rupees twenty five thousand, negotiable, maybe!).

unnormalised: Then comes the security deposit – usually a few months' rent. In Mumbai, it's common to see 2-3 months as security. Make sure that's clearly stated, along with how and when it'll be returned (within 30 days of you moving out, after deducting for damages, naturally).
normalised: Then comes the security deposit – usually a few months' rent. In Mumbai, it's common to see two to three months as security. Make sure that's clearly stated, along with how and when it'll be returned (within thirty days of you moving out, after deducting for damages, naturally).

unnormalised: Duration of the lease is super important. Is it an 11-month agreement (the most common in India, cleverly avoiding registration fees sometimes!) or a longer-term lease? What's the start date (01/10/2024) and end date (31/08/2025)?
normalised: Duration of the lease is super important. Is it an eleven-month agreement (the most common in India, cleverly avoiding registration fees sometimes!) or a longer-term lease? What's the start date (first october two thousand and twenty four) and end date (thirty first august two thousand and twenty five)?

unnormalised: Don't forget about maintenance charges! Who pays what? Is Priya responsible for the society maintenance, or is Mr. Sharma footing that bill? And what about things like minor repairs? If the geyser breaks down, who calls the plumber?
normalised: Don't forget about maintenance charges! Who pays what? Is Priya responsible for the society maintenance, or is Mister Sharma footing that bill? And what about things like minor repairs? If the geyser breaks down, who calls the plumber?

unnormalised: Finally, read the fine print! Notice period (usually 1-2 months), rules about pets (can fluffy stay?), and any other specific clauses that apply to the property.
normalised: Finally, read the fine print! Notice period (usually one to two months), rules about pets (can fluffy stay?), and any other specific clauses that apply to the property.

unnormalised: Getting a registered agreement offers better legal protection but involves extra cost. Weigh your options! A little planning now can save you a lot of stress later, especially if things go south during Diwali or Onam, when everyone's busy celebrating!
